JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The respondent Government were represented by Mr P. Laptev , a former Representative of GPE at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

In DATE the applicant married Mr PERSON and they started living together at the applicant ’s flat on the GPE Street in GPE . In DATE they moved into a CARDINAL - room flat on FAC in GPE ( “ the flat ” ) . The flat was owned by the district council ; PERSON and his son NORP , born in DATE , had their “ registered place of residence ” in the flat . In DATE D. ’s wife gave birth to a son and NORP moved with his family to his wife ’s flat . As NORP never consented to privatisation of the flat , it remained in the ownership of the district council . The applicant contributed to payment of rent and maintenance charges .

In DATE NORP asked his father and the applicant either to repay him CARDINAL of the flat ’s value , or to exchange it for CARDINAL smaller ones . The applicant and PERSON had no money , so NORP sought a court order for exchange .
On DATE the Izmaylovskiy ORG of GPE refused to issue the order as the terms of exchange offered by NORP were not satisfactory .
On DATE the applicant brought separate proceedings against NORP , seeking a court declaration upholding her right of residence in the flat .

On DATE ORG granted NORP ’s claim and ordered that PERSON move to a QUANTITY room in a CARDINAL - room “ communal ” flat . It dismissed PERSON ’s objections to the move relating to the applicant ’s frail health , finding as follows :

“ PERSON ’s wife [ the applicant ] has not acquired the right of residence in the contested flat in accordance with the established procedure , her right to reside [ in the flat ] has not been confirmed , whereas the plaintiff [ NORP ] does not recognise that she should have such a right . ”
The court concluded that in these circumstances the move would not impair PERSON ’s rights and interests .

On DATE ORG refused the applicant ’s claim for recognition of her right of residence . PERSON joined the proceedings as a third party and supported the applicant ’s claim . The court found as follows :

“ It has been established at the hearing that in DATE the plaintiff [ the applicant ] moved into the contested flat as the tenant PERSON ’s family member and that she has lived in the flat up to the present day . The defendant [ D. ] has not contested these circumstances .

However , the plaintiff ’s claim ... can not be granted because ... there is no evidence that [ NORP ] had contented to her moving - in and residing in the contested flat and [ NORP ] denies that he has ever consented ...

Moreover , the plaintiff is a registered tenant of a flat on the FAC , she is on the waiting list for improvement of her housing conditions and contributes to payment of maintenance charges at her registered place of residence . ”
On DATE ORG upheld that judgment on appeal .
On DATE ORG also upheld the judgment of DATE .
The RSFSR Housing Code of DATE ( as amended on DATE , effective at the material time ) provided :

“ The tenant ’s family members shall include the tenant ’s spouse , children and parents . Other relatives , disabled dependants , and – in exceptional circumstances – other persons may be recognised as the tenant ’s family members if they live together with the tenant and maintain a joint household . ”

“ The tenant shall be entitled to accommodate in his living LOC , in accordance with the established procedure , his spouse , children , parents , other relatives , disabled dependants and other persons , subject to written consent of all adult members of his family ...

The persons accommodated by the tenant in accordance with the rules of the present article shall have the same right to use the living premises as the tenant or other members of his family provided that such persons are , or have been recognised as , members of the tenant ’s family ( LAW ) and that no other agreement on the use of the LOC has been signed between these persons , the tenant and his family members . ”

“ If family members fail to agree to an exchange , any family member may seek a court order for a forced exchange of the flat occupied by them for living premises in different blocks of flats . In these proceedings regard must be had to meritorious arguments and interests of the residents of the exchanged flat . ”
